From personal experience - tornado sirens are useful. It may not be useful for other types of weather, but it is used regularly in MN. answers.author: Jessica Roth
answers.text:
We had that same debate earlier this spring here in Suwanee, GA after a tornado came through our city.  We looked into sirens but they are expensive up front and have limited utility.  We ultimately decided to go with the CodeRED notification system, which allows us to provide severe weather and other types of public safety emergency alerts, as well as general, non-emergency messages about city events, programs, etc.  We are launching the system later this month.  We have been impressed with the level of sophistication the system offers and we anticipate it will cost us about $10k/year.

answers.author: Gregory Preece
answers.text:
The county where I live/work recently changed their policy as it was sometimes confusing, in my opinion, as to whether the alert was for a tornado or a severe thunderstorm warning with a tornado watch (the old policy).  I think they still have a role in providing warning, but I too believe with GPS technology in mobile devices that there may be better methods of notifying people more efficiently.  I have provided the link for our county's latest policy.
http://www.hamiltoncountyohioema.org/pdfs/siren_activation_criteria_2011.pdf

answers.author: Michael Smith
answers.text:
As an Emergency Manager, I encourage jurisdictions to use multiple methods to disseminate warnings and emergency public information.  Do not put all your eggs in one basket and rely solely on one method.  You must have redundancy in your warning methods, low tech to high tech, as systems can become inoperative or fail for a variety of reasons (power outages, no internet connectivity, storm damage, cyber attack, etc).  Depending on a person’s age, gender, culture, experience, education, disability, and many more factors, they will get their information from different sources and therefore you have to have multiple methods for a diverse population.  Also, over the last several years there have been instances across the country where some of the newer technologies or methods failed to transmit or disseminate warnings.
The City of OKC has 182 Outdoor Warning Sirens, one of the largest in the country.  Outdoor Warning Systems (OWS) are but one method to warn the public.  OWS is intended to warn people who are outdoors not indoors.  If you are indoors, then All-Hazard Alert Weather Radios would be a good method to receive the warnings.  
Mass notification systems such as CodeRed, IRIS, and many more can get voice and text messages to a variety of electronic devices and in a format accessible to people with disabilities.  I have found challenges using a mass notification system to provide warnings for no notice events such as tornadoes in a city of our size and population.  Mass notification systems have limitations and I have not found a system that can warn enough people fast enough to meet our needs.  You cannot bet the speed at which OWS transmits a warning.  However, if I needed to warn a smaller segment of our city/population of a location specific hazard, then a mass notification system may be appropriate.  The estimated costs we received from vendors for these systems for a city of our size made them inefficient to be used for only warnings, so consider using them for other purposes such as water, waste water, and sold waste service interruption notifications.  
The recent implementation of the Commercial Mobile Alert System (CMAS) and Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA) enables people to receive alerts/warnings on their CMAS/WEA enabled cell phones from participating cell phone providers.  To learn more, go to http://www.fema.gov/commercial-mobile-alert-system .
Do not overlook social media such as Twitter and Facebook to send out warnings and emergency public information.
Attached is the Central Oklahoma Regional Outdoor Warning System Guidelines released in February 2011.  We primarily use our OWS for tornado warnings.  In fact, in our area, people expect to hear the sirens at the same time they receive the warning by another method.
Franklin N. Barnes, CEM®
Emergency Manager
Oklahoma City Emergency Management
Office (405) 605-8981
franklin.barnes@okc.gov

author: Greg Sund
text: Does anyone have an emergency siren policy.  I am trying to get a sense of whether they still have a use given that they are outdoor warning devices, there are many more resources for warning people today, and the fact people tend to use sirens as notification to go outside and look for storms.
title: Emergency Siren Policies
